tabs.header_iregular:
Let's figure out what will help with this pink eye of yours.

First thing to remember is that infectious pink eye is contagious.

You should follow preventive measures to prevent spreading it or reinfection.

Secondly, nothing over the counter for bacteria related pink eye.

Viral pink eye may require no treatment except you have a reduced immune system.

Allergy related pink eye will require some eye drops. These are available over the counter.

With this in mind, see what is recommended below.


Let's use this information to figure out how to take care of this pinkeye.
tabs.header:
Which of the symptoms listed below are you experiencing right now?

Choose your symptoms from the list below and see what is recommended.
fieldset: There is thick pus / discharge coming from the eye.
Only one eye is affected.
Eyelids get stuck together on waking in the morning.
Just watery discharge and no thick pus.
Feel as if there is a foreign object in the eye but no sneezing or runny nose.
I am also experiencing runny nose, sneezing and other allergy symptoms.
Eye got red quickly and is puffy.
This is itchy and burning.
Caused by using contact lens.
A chemical got in the eye.
Prevention only
None of these

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.
mode.2: Something to prevent?
mode.3:
All of these?
You must have this pinkeye really bad.
mode.4:
Contact Lens?
You should seek urgent or emergency care for this.
mode.5:
Chemical?
Go to the nearest emergency room.

The effect of the chemical is still going on. You have to idea when it will end and you risk damaging your eyes.
mode.6: Selection require an allergy pinkeye management approach.
mode.7: Selection require a viral pinkeye management approach.
mode.8: Selection require you to see a doctor.
mode.9: Symptoms require an allergy and viral pinkeye management approach.
mode.10: Symptoms require an allergy pinkeye management approach and for you to see a doctor.
mode.11: Symptoms require a viral pinkeye management approach and for you to seek urgent care.
mode.12: Symptoms require allergy, viral pinkeye management approach and for you to definitely seek urgent care.
mode.50: Oops!, You told me nothing

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/27/2016 at 07:59:am

tabs.header: Know this about the safe and effective use of this recommendation.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header_iregular:
Taking care of the red eye depends on what is causing it.

Hope you yielded our advice to see specific topics for a more detailed and specific discussion of red eyes.

For instance, if it is caused by allergies, you will need an allergy relief eye drop. This is discussed in the allergy relief section.

If you are just looking at a red eye and want to see what you can use over the counter, then see what I recommend below.
tabs.header:
Taking care of the red eye depends on what is causing it.

Hope you yielded our advice to see specific topics for a more detailed and specific discussion of red eyes.

For instance, if it is caused by allergies, you will need an allergy relief eye drop. This is discussed in the allergy relief section.

If you are just looking at a red eye and want to see what you can use over the counter, then see what I recommend below.

collapsable.title: Cold compress click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Use a cold compress to reduce the dilation of the blood vessels on the surface of the eye.

If you have the time, place cucumber in the freezer for about 10 to 15 minutes, cut into slices and place the slice over your eyes to use as a cold compress.

This will also help with circles under the eyes and wrinkles on and near the eyelids while you are at it.

collapsable.title: Eye drops click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Eye drops for red eyes act by constricting the blood vessels that have dilated on the surface of the eyes. This makes them less noticeable.

You may need help choosing a good eye drops for red eyes. For this reason I have included a comparison table for eye drops for redness relief.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 09/10/2014

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's figure out what to do about this stye.

Most styes usually go away on their own. Some cases may require antibiotic ointment or even oral antibiotics like doxycycline which are not available over the counter.

Eye ointments for stye over the counter mainly contain petroleum jelly to soothe the sty.

All is not lost though. See what I recommend below.

collapsable.title: Warm compress click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Apply a warm compress about 4 to 6 times a day for about 5-10 minutes each time.

Keep your eyes closed while doing this.

collapsable.title: Eyelid hygiene click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Eyelid hygiene would require you to gently scrub the infected eyelid with water and/or  a nonirritating soap like baby shampoo.

collapsable.title: Pain relievers click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Take some ibuprofen or naproxen if you can to help with tenderness and pain.

collapsable.title: Eye Lubricants click to expand contents
collapsable.content: These mainly contain petroleum jelly to soothe eye movement.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Depending on how bad it is and how desperate you are, get triple antibiotic ointment or cream and gently dab it on the affected area outside the eye.
    Know that this is not meant for the eye as it is not sterile. Try avoiding the eyes as much as possible and only use it while awake.
    Wash off before going to sleep.
     
  2. Do NOT attempt to squeeze or lance it.
    Let it drain on its own.
    If it does not drain in 2 to 3 days, then it is time to see a doctor.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 09/11/2014

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what will work over-the-counter for this dry eyes.

Treating dry eyes depends on the cause. Some conditions can be managed or reversed. 

Others require a more detailed evaluation by a healthcare professional.

Treating dry eyes is usually done through the means listed below.

We encourage you to take a look at them and then we will use the approaches available over-the-counter to see what will work best for your dry eyes by answering a few questions.
tabs.header:
Which of the symptoms listed below are you experiencing right now?

Which of these apply to your dry eye situation assuming you used the "grade your dry eye" tool.
fieldset: Looking at moderate to severe dry eyes.
I do have mild dry eyes
Eye is burning and very irritated
It feels worse when I first wake up in the morning.
Eyes get really painful at times
Feels like there is sand in my eyes.
I have been using dry eye drops more than 4 times a day.
Vision gets blurry most of the time.
Prevention only
None of these

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.
mode.2: Something to prevent?
mode.3:
All of these?
You must have this dry eye really bad.
mode.4: Selection require a thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops.
mode.5: Selection require a watery artificial tears eye drops.
mode.6: Selection require a night time lubricant eye gel or ointment.
mode.7: Selection require a cold or warm compress.
mode.8: Selection require a preservative free artificial tears eye drops.
mode.9: Symptoms require a thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops and probably a watery artificial tears eye drops.
mode.10: Symptoms require a thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops and a night time lubricant eye gel.
mode.11: Symptoms require a thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops and a cold or warm compress.
mode.12: Symptoms require a thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops and preservative free.
mode.13: Symptoms require a watery artificial tears eye drops and a night time lubricant eye gel.
mode.14: Symptoms require a watery artificial tears eye drops and cold or warm compress.
mode.15: Symptoms require a watery artificial tears eye drops and preservative free.
mode.16: Symptoms require a night time lubricant eye gel and a cold or warm compress.
mode.17: Symptoms require a night time lubricant eye gel and should be preservative free.
mode.18: Symptoms require a cold or warm compress and preservative free lubricant eye drops
mode.19: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, watery artificial tears eye drops and a night time lubricant eye gel.
mode.20: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, watery artificial tears eye drops and a cold or warm compress
mode.21: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, watery artificial tears eye drops and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.22: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, night time lubricant eye gel and a cold or warm compress.
mode.23: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, night time lubricant eye gel and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.24: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, cold or warm compress and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.25: Symptoms require watery artificial tears eye drops, night time lubricant eye gel and a cold or warm compress.
mode.26: Symptoms require watery artificial tears eye drops, night time lubricant eye gel and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.27: Symptoms require watery artificial tears eye drops, cold or warm compress and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.28: Symptoms require night time lubricant eye gel, cold or warm compress and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.29: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, watery artificial tears eye drops, night time lubricant eye gel and a cold or warm compress.
mode.30: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, watery artificial tears eye drops, night time lubricant eye gel and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.31: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, watery artificial tears eye drops, cold or warm compress and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.32: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, night time lubricant eye gel, cold or warm compress and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.33: Symptoms require watery artificial tears eye drops, night time lubricant eye gel, cold or warm compress and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.34: Symptoms require thicker or viscous artificial tears eye drops, watery artificial tears eye drops, night time lubricant eye gel, cold or warm compress and a preservative free eye drops.
mode.50: Oops!, You told me nothing

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/27/2016 at 09:24:am

collapsable.title: Lubrication click to expand contents
collapsable.content: These include artificial tears, lubricant eye gels and ointments.

collapsable.title: Punctal plugs click to expand contents
collapsable.content: To plug the drainage duct of tears in the eye.

collapsable.title: Steroidal eye drops click to expand contents
collapsable.content: For inflammation.

collapsable.title: Restasis click to expand contents
collapsable.content: How does it work?

collapsable.title: Oral antibiotics click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Like doxycycline.

collapsable.title: Others click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Warm compress
  2. Omega 3 oils
  3. Eye lid scrubs.

collapsable.title: Preventive measures click to collapse contents
Thicker / Viscous Artificial Tears click to expand contents
Watery Artificial Tears click to expand contents
Night Time Lubricant Gel click to expand contents
Cold / Warm Compress click to expand contents
Preservative Free click to expand contents
Worth doing click to expand contents

irregular.content:
Of these, the approaches available over-the-counter are:

  1. Lubricant eye gels or ointments

  2. Artifical tears

  3. Eye lid scrubs

  4. Taking omega3 vitamins

  5. Applying a warm compress

Let's use this information to choose a good over-the-counter remedy assuming you used the "grade your dry eye tool" provided by refresh brand to get your dry eye severity OSDI score.

You can get the tool here if you need to. Remember to come back and see what to use over-the-counter.
